thread.section_title: Latest business and finance news from New Zealand and the world's key markets - Yahoo New Zealand Finance
thread.title: Aussie stocks on rollercoaster ride

title: Aussie stocks on rollercoaster ride
text:
Tue, Aug 25, 2015, 1:46 PM NZST - New Zealand Markets close in 3 hrs 14 mins Aussie stocks on rollercoaster ride AAP – 18 minutes ago Print 
The Australian stock market has had a rollercoaster ride at the start of trade after panic selling offshore overnight. 
The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 and the All Ordinaries both dived 1.5 per cent to below the 5,000 point mark within the opening minutes of trade on Tuesday amid mounting concerns about China's economy. 
However, within half an hour, a recovery among the heavyweight banking stocks helped the market claw back its losses and to even push it briefly into positive territory. 
Traders had expected the market to extend its four per cent losses from Monday's session due to heavy falls on Wall Street and across Europe overnight. 
The Australian market's tumble on Monday was sparked by a dive of more than eight per cent in the Shanghai Composite, the latest in a series of falls that have wiped trillions off the Chinese market. 
Bank stocks climbed back into positive territory on Tuesday, while mining giant Rio Tinto pushed one per cent higher and Woolworths climbed by more than two per cent. 
But elsewhere, BHP Billiton was down about one per cent and Telstra had slumped three per cent after paying out its latest dividend. 
Traders said all eyes were on the Chinese market, which is due to open at 1130 AEST. 
Falls in commodity prices, including a slump in the oil price to about $US38 a barrel, kept most energy stocks in the red. 
Despite recent soft manufacturing data from China and the devaluation of the yuan having heightened investor nervousness head of equity strategies at BT Investment Management Crispin Murray said he did not believe the outlook for China's economy had deteriorated significantly. 
The US economy was also strong enough to withstand a gradual increase in interest rates, he said. 
Mr Murray added that reduced liquidity across global markets during the northern hemisphere summer was also playing a role in the sell-off. 
"The recent correction is reasonable and not out of the ordinary," he said. 
"The underlying concern is global economic growth, but we do not foresee this materially decelerating." 
CMC Markets chief market strategist Michael McCarthy said the drivers of the selling were not simple. 
"Some analysts are pointing to a stronger US dollar threatening fragile emerging market economies, others point to weaker China manufacturing data and a 36 per cent fall in the Shanghai composite index," he said. 
"The continuing falls in copper and oil point to a souring of global industrial sentiment." 
Meanwhile, Treasurer Joe Hockey has sought to soothe investor nerves, saying "to be calm is good advice". 
He noted that the Chinese market was still more than 40 per cent higher than a year ago despite its economy having slowed a "little bit". @YahooNZBusiness on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Treasurer promises tax cuts and surplus AAP
